importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The article was published on this date, marking the day when Sir Philip Pullman publicly calls on the UK government to act on AI scraping of writers' works.

The release date of The Rose Field: The Book of Dust Volume Three, which completes the trilogy about Lyra Silvertongue and is set for publication on this date, including an audiobook narrated by Michael Sheen.

The UK government launched a consultation on copyright laws related to AI and creative industries in December 2024, which received 11,500 responses and led to the formation of expert working groups on AI and copyright.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period from 2024 to 2025 marks the key timeframe during which the UK government is reviewing copyright laws in response to AI scraping of creative works, with Sir Philip Pullman's public appeals occurring in 2025.

keyTakeAways: Sir Philip Pullman is urging the UK government to reform copyright laws to stop AI companies from scraping writers' books without compensation.
Writers such as Kate Mosse and Richard Osman argue that AI scraping constitutes theft and threatens the sustainability of creative industries.
Pullman believes that authors should be paid when their work is used to train AI systems, calling it immoral and not illegal.
The government launched a consultation on AI and copyright in late 2024, receiving over 11,500 responses and establishing expert working groups.
Pullman's novels, especially the His Dark Materials series, explore themes of imagination, curiosity, and the suppression of creative thought by authoritarian institutions.
He explicitly denies being a fantasy writer, stating his work is about the real world filtered through imagination and not fantasy in the traditional sense.
He identifies the education system and organized religion as real-world threats to imagination, which is central to his storytelling.
The final volume of the Lyra trilogy, The Rose Field, is set to be released on 23 October 2025, with a new audiobook version narrated by Michael Sheen.
Pullman reflects on his own childhood and is working on a memoir about it, and speculates that his daemon would be a corvid (raven), citing their intelligence and mythological role as storytellers.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Sir Philip Pullman, best known for his Lyra Silvertongue series, has publicly urged the UK government to revise copyright laws to prevent AI companies from scraping writers' books without compensation or recognition. He describes the practice as immoral and akin to theft, arguing that authors should be paid when their work is used to train AI systems. This issue gained urgency after a government consultation on AI and copyright in late 2024 received over 11,500 responses. Pullman's critique extends to real-world institutions, such as education systems and organized religion, which he believes suppress imagination — a theme central to his fiction. The final volume of his Book of Dust trilogy, The Rose Field, is set for release on 23 October 2025, with an audiobook narrated by Michael Sheen. Pullman also reflects on his own childhood and speculates that his daemon would be a raven, linking his personal identity to the themes of intelligence and storytelling.
title: Author Philip Pullman calls on government to act over 'wicked' AI scraping
